question:

Consider the differentiable function $f:\mathbb{R}^{2}\rightarrow \mathbb{R},$ $%
f(x,y)=e^{ax^{2}+by^{2}}$. It satisfies the equations:
answer1:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}\left( x,y\right) =2axf(x,y),
\dfrac{\partial^{2}f}{\partial x^{2}}\left( x,y\right) =\left( 2a+4a^{2}x^{2}\right) f(x,y),%
\dfrac{\partial ^{2}f}{\partial x\partial y}(x,y)=4abxyf(x,y).$
answer2:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}\left( x,y\right) =2af(x,y),\dfrac{\partial
^{2}f}{\partial x^{2}}\left( x,y\right) =\left( 2a+4a^{2}x^{2}\right) f(x,y),%
\dfrac{\partial ^{2}f}{\partial x\partial y}(x,y)=4abxyf(x,y).$
answer3:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}\left( x,y\right) =2axf(x,y),\dfrac{\partial
^{2}f}{\partial x^{2}}\left( x,y\right) =\left( 2a+4a^{2}x\right) f(x,y),%
\dfrac{\partial ^{2}f}{\partial x\partial y}(x,y)=4abf(x,y).$
answer4:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}\left( x,y\right) =2axf(x,y),\dfrac{\partial
^{2}f}{\partial x^{2}}\left( x,y\right) =\left( 2a+4a^{2}x^{2}\right) f(x,y),%
\dfrac{\partial ^{2}f}{\partial x\partial y}(x,y)=4bxyf(x,y).$

question:

$p=q+r$

For which $\left(a,\,b\right) \in \mathbb{R}^2$ does the following linear system has infinitely many solutions?
$$\begin{cases}
x & + & by & + & az & = & 1 \\
x & + & aby & + & z & = & b \\
ax & + & by & + & z & = & 1
\end{cases}$$
answer4: There is no pair $(a,b)\in\mathbb{R}^{2}$ for which the linear system has infinitely many solutions.

question:
Consider the table

$$\begin{array}{c|ccc}
x & 2 & 2.5 & 4   \\
\hline
y & 0.5 & 0.4 & 0.25 \\
\end{array}$$

Find the Lagrange's polynomial.

How many solutions does the following linear system has?
$$\begin{cases}
x & + & 2y & = & 4 \\
x & - & 2y & = & 0 \\
4x & + & 3y & = & 12
\end{cases}$$
answer2: The system has $\left(2,\,1\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The system has $\left(\frac{24}{11},\,\frac{12}{11}\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4: The system has an infinite number of solutions of the form $\left(2y,\,y\right)$ for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.

question:
The linear application $F: \mathbb{R}^3\rightarrow \mathbb{R}^3$ is represented by matrix 
$$A=\left[\begin{array}{rrr}
 -1  & 2 & 0\\
 0 & 1 & 2 \\
  3 & 2  & 1
  \end{array}\right]$$
when considered the canonical basis of $\mathbb{R}^3$. The analytic expression of $F$ is:

Consider the matrix 
$$A_k=\left[\begin{array}{rrr}
 1  & 1  & 0 \\
  -1 & -k  & k-1 \\
  3 & 2  & 2k+1
\end{array}\right]$$
and denote by $L(A_k)$ the space of the rows of the matrix $A_k$. Which of the following statements is true?
answer1: If $k\in \mathbb{R}\backslash \{0, 1\}$ then the dimension of $L(A_k)$ is $3$
answer2: The dimension of $L(A_k)$ is $3$ for every $k\in \mathbb{R}$
answer3: If $k\in \mathbb{R}\backslash \{0\}$ then the dimension of $L(A_k)$ is $3$
answer4: If $k\in \mathbb{R}\backslash \{0, -1\}$ then the dimension of $L(A_k)$ is $3$

question:
Ralph Edmund loves steaks and potatoes. Therefore, he has decided to go on a steady diet of only these two foods (plus some liquids and vitamin supplements) for all his meals. Ralph realizes that this isn't the healthiest diet, so he wants to make sure that he eats the right quantities of the two foods to satisfy some key nutritional requirements. He has obtained the following nutritional and cost information:

\[
\begin{array}{|l|c|c|c|}
\hline
%& \multicolumn{2}{c|}{Grams of ingredient per serving} &\\
\text{Ingredient} & \text{Steak (gr. per serving)} & \text{Potatoes (gr. per serving)} & \text{Daily Requirements (gr.)} \\
\hline
\text{Carbohydrates} & 5 & 15 & \geq 50 \\
\text{Protein} & 20 & 5 & \geq 40 \\
\text{Fat} & 15 & 2 & \leq 60 \\
\hline
\text{Cost per serving} & 4 & 2 &  \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]
	
Use a computer (Solver Add-in in Excel) to solve this model by the simplex method to allow planning the Ralph's diet, considering that $x_{i}$ is the number of daily servings of food $i$ ($i=1$, for steak and $i=2$, for potatoes).

Find the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
2x &+ &y &- &z &= &1 \\ 
x &+ &y &+ &z &= &2 \\ 
x &- &y &- &z &= &0
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\left(1,0,1\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The system has $\left(1,0,1\right)$ and $\left(1,0,-1\right)$ as its solutions.
answer4: The system has $\left(x,0,x\right)$ as solution for every $x\in\mathbb{R}$.

answer1: If the kernel of a linear transformation $T:\mathbb{R}^3\longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^3$ is $\left\{(0,0,0)\right\}$, then $T$ is an isomorphism.
answer2: If the kernel of a linear transformation $T:\mathbb{R}^3\longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^4$ is $\left\{(0,0,0)\right\}$, then $T$ is an isomorphism.

question: If $u=(1,-2,\lambda)$ and $v=(-2,4,5)$ are linearly dependent vectors of $\mathbb{R}^3$, indicate what value can $\lambda$ assume.

Classify the critical points of $f(x,y)=x^3-3xy+y^3$.
answer1: $(1,1)$ is a minimum and $(0,0)$ is a saddle point.
answer2: $(1,1)$ is a saddle point and $(0,0)$ is a minimum.
answer3: $(1,1)$ and $(-1,-1)$ are a saddle points and $(0,0)$ is a minimum.
answer4: $(1,1)$ and $(-1,-1)$ are minima and $(0,0)$ is a saddle point.

question: Consider the linear operator $F:\mathbb{R}^2 \longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^2$ such that $F(x,y)=(x+2y,2x+3y)$. Choose the right answer:
answer1: $F^{-1}$ is a symmetric operator defined by $F^{-1}(x,y)=(-3x+2y, 2x-y)$
answer3: $F^{-1}$ is defined by $F^{-1}(x,y)=(3x-2y, -2x+y)$ and is not a symmetric operator
answer4: $F^{-1}$ is a symmetric operator defined by $F^{-1}(x,y)=(3x-2y, 2x-y)$

question: The study of oak heights was conducted in the Wolf forest, which has approximately $1000$ oaks. The heights of $10$ randomly chosen oaks from this forest are $20, 18, 19, 25, 30, 22, 29, 21, 17,$ and $20$. What is the sample size in this study?
